author: Leticia Montserrat Aguirre Rodriguez
title: Katy Perry, Lauren Sánchez y Gayle King viajarán al espacio en el cohete de Jeff Bezzos
text:
Katy Perry, Lauren Sánchez y Gayle King viajarán al espacio en el cohete de Jeff Bezzos
La estrella del pop Katy Perry, la prometida de Jeff Bezos, Lauren Sánchez, y la reconocida presentadora de noticias Gayle King se encuentran entre las seis mujeres que formarán parte del próximo vuelo espacial de Blue Origin.
La empresa aeroespacial de Bezos anunció que esta misión marcará la primera tripulación compuesta exclusivamente por mujeres en viajar al espacio en décadas.
¿Por qué la misión de Blue Origin solo contará con mujeres?
El jueves, Blue Origin reveló la lista oficial de tripulantes para la próxima misión de su programa New Shepard. Junto a Perry, Sánchez y King, viajarán la ex científica de cohetes de la NASA Aisha Bowe, la científica investigadora y activista Amanda Nguyen y la productora de cine Kerianne Flynn.
Este nuevo vuelo de Blue Origin representa un momento significativo para la inclusión de las mujeres en la exploración espacial comercial y destaca el creciente interés de las empresas privadas en ampliar el acceso al turismo espacial.
El vuelo, programado para la primavera de 2025, tendrá una duración de 11 minutos y llevará a la tripulación más allá de la línea de Kármán, el punto que marca el límite internacionalmente reconocido entre la atmósfera terrestre y el espacio exterior, a unas 62 millas sobre la superficie de la Tierra.
Según Blue Origin, la nave New Shepard es completamente autónoma, por lo que ningún miembro de la tripulación tendrá que pilotarla.
TE PUEDE INTERESAR: Katy Perry: las reacciones de su “perturbadora” visita a México
¿Cuándo fue la última vez que una tripulación femenina viajó al espacio?
La última vez que una tripulación femenina viajó al espacio fue el 16 de junio de 1963, cuando la cosmonauta soviética Valentina Tereshkova se convirtió en la primera mujer en volar sola al espacio en una misión de tres días a bordo del Vostok 6. Desde entonces, muchas mujeres han participado en misiones espaciales, pero siempre como parte de tripulaciones mixtas.
Desde 2021, Blue Origin ha llevado a cabo más de 10 vuelos tripulados, enviando al espacio a clientes privados y figuras destacadas.
En julio de 2021, el propio Jeff Bezos participó en el primer vuelo de New Shepard. Meses después, en octubre de ese mismo año, el actor de Star Trek, William Shatner, hizo historia al convertirse en la persona de mayor edad en viajar al espacio, con 90 años.
La mayoría de los pasajeros de New Shepard pagan por su asiento, aunque algunas figuras notables, como Shatner, han volado como invitados. Para aquellos que desean vivir la experiencia, Blue Origin exige un depósito reembolsable de 150.000 dólares, aunque el precio exacto del boleto no ha sido revelado. Se estima que un asiento cuesta al menos 200.000 dólares, mientras que el primer boleto vendido en una subasta alcanzó los 28 millones de dólares en 2021.
TE RECOMENDAMOS: 5 cosas que debes de saber del viaje de Jeff Bezos al espacio
¿Con quiénes compite Jeff Bezos por el turismo espacial?
Fundada por Jeff Bezos, Blue Origin compite con otras empresas privadas como SpaceX, de Elon Musk, y Virgin Galactic, de Richard Branson, en la expansión del turismo espacial.
Hasta ahora, la empresa ha enviado a más de 24 personas al espacio y ha realizado 19 misiones no tripuladas con el objetivo de transportar experimentos científicos y datos de investigación.
Sin embargo, el cohete New Shepard ha enfrentado desafíos. En septiembre de 2022, sufrió un lanzamiento fallido que llevó a la Administración Federal de Aviación (FAA) a abrir una investigación. Un año después, en 2023, la FAA concluyó que Blue Origin debía tomar medidas correctivas, incluidas mejoras en el diseño del motor y la boquilla del cohete.
A pesar de estos contratiempos, la empresa sigue avanzando en su misión de hacer del espacio un destino accesible para más personas, y su próximo vuelo exclusivamente femenino marca un nuevo capítulo en esta ambiciosa historia.

author: Mark Swanson
title: House GOP Moves to Reverse Biden's Trans Protections
text: By Mark Swanson | Thursday, 06 June 2024 05:49 PM EDT House Republicans are mounting a federal challenge to the sweeping Title IX "violations" instituted by the Biden administration's rule of federal protections for transgender students. Rep. Mary Miller, R-Ill., and at least 67 of her Republican colleagues are leading an effort to reverse the Department of Education's final rule issued in late April that changes federal law on sex discrimination in schools to include sexual orientation and gender identity for the first time. That includes allowing biological boys and men into women's locker rooms. Running afoul of the new rule would endanger federal funding schools receive. More than 20 states have filed lawsuits and legal challenges and issued orders to ignore the changes that are slated to take effect Aug. 1. Miller is leading the federal response with the disapproval resolution. "Joe Biden is undermining years of progress women have made in securing their rights under Title IX. For more than half a century, Title IX has protected women and girls, ensuring they have equal opportunities in education," Miller said Wednesday in a news release. "This divergence is a blatant violation of the protections Title IX was meant to guarantee, and it undermines the very foundation of women's rights and security in their private spaces." The myriad legal challenges mounted by states will almost certainly block the rule changes from taking effect in several weeks. Former President Donald Trump has vowed to reverse it on Day 1 if he's re-elected. "The Biden administration's final rule hacks Title IX into pieces and expunges decades of progress for women and girls across the nation. This is a clear and present threat, and one that cannot go unaddressed," Rep. Virginia Foxx, R-N.C., chair of the Education and the Workforce Committee, said in the release. author: Christian Gardner christian.gardner@averyjournal.com
title: CELEBRATING TRADITION: Tartan colors fill MacRae Meadows at 69th Highland Games
text:
GRANDFATHER MOUNTAIN — The 69th annual Grandfather Mountain Highland Games returned to Avery County’s MacRae Meadows July 10 to 13, drawing tens of thousands of spectators to celebrate Scottish culture amidst the scenic backdrop of the Blue Ridge Mountains. Over four full days, the event blended fiercely competitive athletics with spirited pageantry and ancestral traditions.
More than a hundred Scottish clans assembled on Thursday, each setting up tents adorned with tartan banners for the ceremonial “Calling of the Clans.” The torchlight ceremony, a glowing bonfire procession, then brought the Highland traditions to life as pipers led the clans into the evening air.
The Games showcased a range of Highland sports, from the iconic caber toss and sheaf toss to heavy hammer and weight throw contests. The games hosted divisions for “A” and “B” amateurs, professionals and Masters, with this year’s addition of an Elite Women’s Invitational Competition. Organizers hope to expand opportunities for women in the future.
The Caber Toss remains the most iconic event, as athletes aim to flip the log to land in the “12 o’clock” position, with style taking priority over distance.
Piping and drumming bands filled the air, while internationally ranked highland dancers performed in official Atlantic Championship competitions. Attendees also enjoyed sheepdog herding exhibitions, Celtic concerts, including a Friday night rock jam and a lively Scottish country dance gala.
The 2025 Games were treated as a testament to what had happened last September in the High Country when Hurricane Helene swept through. Notably, the Games did not escape unscathed weather-wise during this year’s weekend, as heavy storms remained prevalent intermittently throughout the festival.
GMHG President Steve Quillen praised the swift recovery following Hurricane Helene and the enduring community spirit, mentioning that the restored grounds looked “like Helene never showed up,” a testament to the dedication of the staff and volunteers.
“I can’t express enough gratitude to all our staff and volunteers. Even with the torrential rain we had this weekend, the grounds held up exceptionally well,” said Quillen.
The 2025 Grandfather Mountain Highland Games once again delivered a memorable blend of athletic prowess, cultural pageantry, and hometown camaraderie. As tradition continues to echo through the valley, locals and visitors alike are already looking forward to next summer’s return to Scotland in the mountains.
For more information on the Games, click to www.gmhg.org.

title: First heat pump collective purchase campaign kicks off in Spain
text:
First heat pump collective purchase campaign kicks off in Spain
Today, Spanish consumer organisation and CLEAR HP partner OCU launches the project’s first collective purchase campaign of heat pumps. In Spain, the distribution and retail sale of these products has diversified and expanded significantly in recent years, driven by growing interest in more sustainable and energy-efficient heating and cooling solutions.
Aerothermal systems, which harness the thermal energy from the outside air to provide heating, cooling, and hot water, have become an attractive option for both retrofitting existing buildings and new constructions.
In 2023, it is estimated that around 180,000 aerothermal heat pumps were installed in Spain, representing a growth of over 200% compared to 2020. However, the cost of these products remains high, and subsidies are insufficient. Therefore, OCU is advocating for an improved subsidy scheme for the purchase and installation of these systems.
Consumers in Spain can now sign up to participate in the campaign here. Signing up is the first step to accessing workshops on effectively adopting this technology. Consumers will also learn more about the advantageous turnkey offer, which includes energy certificates, before and after the installation; a visit from an installer, management of subsidies, tax credits and Energy Saving Certificates (in Spanish ‘CEAs’); installation and start-up, and after-sales service.
Need more information? Watch OCU’s first webinar (in Spanish) on switching to more sustainable heating and cooling solutions which already took place and is now available for everyone.
The CLEAR-HP project was created to facilitate consumers’ access to heat pumps by guiding them throughout the whole purchasing journey. In seven European countries, CLEAR HP project partners aim to promote consumer awareness and empower them to lead the clean energy transition, improving the energy performance and comfort of their homes, and reducing their energy bills.
At the heart of this project are a series of collective purchase campaigns based on ‘purchase and install’ packages, designed and tested to help consumers to adopt renewable heating systems in a simple and transparent way.
The project will continue with the launch of CPCs for heat pumps in Portugal in December 2024, while all other partners will launch their first campaigns in the first half of 2025.
